awd_titl_txt: The development of lexical competition in heritage speakers
awd_abstract_narration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Under the sponsorship of Dr. Bob McMurray at the University of Iowa, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early career scientist examining language development in heritage speaker children. In the current geographical, political, and global climate, immigrant populations are expected to continue increasing around the world. A critical barrier faced by the children of these immigrants is language, as they may not have the same opportunities as monolingual children do to develop the majority language of their new home (Valdés, 2005). Thus, a challenge is posed for understanding the language development of heritage speaker children, as their first language (the heritage language) becomes their less dominant language as they age (often when schooling begins), and their second language (the majority language) eventually becomes dominant, despite a delayed start (Polinsky, 2011). This often relegates them to special English Language Learner classrooms or leaves them with insufficient support. Currently, how heritage speakers develop their dominancy in the majority language and what type of neural changes happen when this language dominancy shift occurs is not well-studied.

The proposed research study aims to understand spoken word recognition, a bottleneck process of early language development (Perfetti, 2007; Verhoeven, Reitsma, & Siegel, 2011), in monolingual and heritage speakers at Grade 1, Grade 4, and in adulthood by using eye-tracking, EEGs, and machine learning. Here, lexical processing—a critical hub in the language system—is being targeted as a model system in which to ask how heritage speakers become more automatic language processors in the majority language and maintain this in their heritage language. Assessing heritage speaker children’s linguistic backgrounds presents a unique challenge in that their exposure to English is not similar to their monolingual peers, and their age and manner of acquisition as well as their proficiency in the majority and the heritage language do not follow previously assessed bilingual norms. Therefore, typical language background questionnaires may not adequately capture heritage speaker children’s experience. Instead, a more holistic approach, including an innovative recording tool (i.e., the LENA system) and network science to quantify the exposure in both languages are employed. Finally, the proposed study aims to not only understand the impact of delayed exposure to the majority language in childhood but also its prolonged impact on heritage speaker adults’ language representation, and to separate the contributions of semantic and auditory differences using electrophysiological and machine learning techniques. Findings here expand on both language acquisition and the cognitive neuroscience of language processing in various bilingual populations (i.e., heritage speakers). Crucially, heritage speakers provide insight to help answer theoretically challenging questions in lexical processing which cannot be otherwise addressed. Overall, this study aims to broaden the participation of heritage speakers in language development research as well as find and create more sustainable language and educational programs for heritage speakers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A fundamental component of the language system is that it shows variation from person to person and from community to community. For instance, while there is individual variability observed when processing language, the same variation can also be observed at the community level. For many decades, though, language and cognitive scientists sought to ignore variability to focus on the underlying representations of human cognition and the language system. This was due in part to the theories being built on communities that are overrepresented in science and in part to methodological limitations to capturing linguistic diversity. This NSF project is proposed to specifically understand linguistic diversity in early bilingual experiences.

More than half of the world’s population is exposed to more than one language. Heritage speakers are those who are exposed to one language at home and maintain another language outside of the home. Theoretically, heritage speakers pose a challenge for language development research which argues that language development happens rapidly during the first couple years of life. For heritage speaker children, language development changes its trajectory when they start schooling. This is when their connection to the majority language is increased while their connection to their heritage language becomes more limited. Therefore, while the two languages coexist in different social contexts, heritage speakers often lose their dominance in their heritage language due to societal boundaries over the use of the heritage language and become more dominant in the majority language. In other words, their language development shifts from one language to the other one when schooling begins.

In a series of studies, we examined heritage children’s English language development by focusing on their speech categorization as well as their word recognition patterns. We focused on word recognition and speech categorization because they play a fundamental role in language development. To achieve our goals, we use a range of novel methods including eye-tracking, the Visual Analog Scale (a new measure of speech perception), and network science. 

Our eye-tracking paradigms record eye movements in a way that allows them to reflect cognitive processes in real-time. For instance, to study word recognition, a listener might hear a target word like “wizard,” and match it to one of four images that represent words they may consider while making that decision; for example, an image of a wizard (target word), an image of a word that begins with the same sound, such as “whistle” (cohort), an image of a word that rhymes with the word “wizard”, such as “lizard” (rhyme), and a word that is unrelated to the target such as “necklace.” Previous research has shown that upon hearing the first part of the word wizard, listeners start looking at the wizard and whistle more than lizard and necklace. When the word is completely heard, listeners were shown to momentarily look at the word lizard, but only for a very brief period of time. Statistically, we can compute which image listeners are considering at what time point to understand how they activate words in their mental lexicon. This approach has not yet been extensively used to understand language processing in heritage language speakers – who may recognize words quite differently. 

We also examined how heritage children from diverse linguistic backgrounds categorize speech sounds. In order to do this, we create auditory stimuli that “morph” between two sounds (e.g., a continuum of steps between beach and peach). We then measure how people respond to this with an ecological task called the Visual Analogue Scaling task, in which people rate how “b-like” or “p-like” each sound was. Critically, we did this with heritage children to see how their speech categorization develops and adapts to the dominant language (which is relatively new for them). A fundamental part of our study was to ensure that we capture linguistic diversity surrounding children. To achieve this goal, we used a social network approach where we mapped linguistic diversity that surrounds each of our participants.

Our findings show that children whose social networks have more linguistic diversity show more linguistic flexibility, both when they are processing words and when they are categorizing speech sounds. Importantly, we found that children’s English language development continues during the first couple years in elementary school. These findings suggest that language development is ongoing and even though heritage speaker children face an abrupt shift from one language to the other one, they adapt to this shift quickly.
